title: Bystander behaviour and the control of violence in the night-time economy
abstractText:
While most types of recorded crime remain stable or are in decline, the number of violent assaults recorded in the night-time economy zones of our towns and cities continues to rise.

This research project draws on recent theoretical work in the social psychology of groups to develop new ways to tackle the problem of violence in the night-time economy. In particular, the research will focus on the importance of the behaviour of bystanders in determining whether violence is prevented, condoned or escalated.

Using a combination of methodologies (a 'mapping' of interactions in the night-time economy space; a series of group interviews with different groups of participants in the night-time economy; an analysis of CCTV footage of violent and non-violent episodes in the night-time economy) the research will focus on the way bystander behaviour is implicated in the trajectory of violence.

The aim of the research will be to see if a focus on the behaviour of bystanders can lead to the development of new intervention strategies for reducing violence in the night-time economy
